text:
I think that OSS is great way to gain a reputation. And reputation is currency in academia. I made Julia an essential part of my first successful grant proposal and when I met with the program manger and asked “what did you like about the proposal?” His first response was “the Julia part” I doubt that I would have been taken as seriously without my experience on LightGraphs.jl. 

The key is to always use the OSS as a tool to do traditional research/scholarship. Nobody wants to pay for maintenance so I would never submit a proposal to fund ongoing maintenance or development of an existing OSS project. But using the experience and network you gain in OSS to lend credibility to a proposal for some novel science, that can work. Also for getting hired as a post doc or research scientist. I’m way more willing to hire someone based on their GitHub commits than their publications.

For example, in my area there is AGU (American Geophysical Union), AMS (American meteorological society) and UGM (Mexican geophysical union), among others.
